Dhaneswar Bhoi is an Indian sociologist and academic. He is an Honorary Fellow in the Department of Sociology at the University of Edinburgh, UK, and a Lecturer at the London School of Science and Technology (LSST). His research focuses on caste dynamics, social exclusion, and educational equity in India.
Bhoi's work centres on the lived experiences of marginalised communities, particularly Dalits and Adivasis. His academic interests include public health, mental health, psycho-social theory, and the impact of neo-liberal policies on disadvantaged groups. He has authored or co-authored over 35 articles, 75 research papers and presented at numerous international conferences. He previously worked with Government of India policy bodies, such as the Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment (MSJE) and the National Council of Educational Research and Training (NCERT).
He is the co-editor of the book Caste in Everyday Life: Experience and Affect in Indian Society (2023), published by Palgrave Macmillan. He also serves as an associate editor and reviewer for several academic journals, including Social Inclusion and the Journal of the World Universities Forum.
Education
Bhoi completed his post-doctoral research at the Centre for South Asian Studies at the University of Edinburgh from 2020 to 2023. He has also undertaken courses in public policy at the Frank Batten School of Leadership and Public Policy, University of Virginia; diversity and inclusion at the University of Michigan; and research methods at SOAS University of London. He is enrolled in a PGCert in Learning and Teaching in Higher Education at the University of London for 2024–2025.
Career and policy work
Academic appointments
Bhoi is currently a Lecturer in Sociology of Health and a Module Leader for Applied Research at the London School of Science and Technology, which collaborates with the University of West London, De Montfort University, and Buckinghamshire New University. Since completing his post-doctoral research, he has held the position of Honorary Fellow in Sociology at the University of Edinburgh.
Previously, he was a Post-Doctoral Fellow at the University of Edinburgh (2020–2023) and a Research Associate at the Centre for Social Justice and Governance at the Tata Institute of Social Sciences (TISS), Mumbai (2011–2016).
Policy consultation
Bhoi has worked extensively with national policy and research bodies within the Government of India. He served as a Researcher and Policy Analyst for the Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment (MSJE) in 2020 and as a Consultant for the Ministry of Human Resource Development (MHRD) from 2018 to 2019, where he provided input on the New Education Policy Draft.
His other roles include serving as a Consultant for the National Council of Educational Research and Training (NCERT) and the National Institute of Educational Planning and Administration (NIEPA), and as a Social Scientist at the Indian Social Institute, New Delhi. In these capacities, he contributed to drafting multiple national and state-level reports on education equity issues.
Invited talks and academic activities
Bhoi frequently presents his research at major academic institutions and international conferences. His book, Caste in Everyday Life, has been the subject of several academic events at leading universities. In June 2024, the book was launched at an event at the London School of Economics (LSE). This was followed by book talks at King's College London in February 2025 and at Stanford University's Center for South Asia in February 2025.
In June 2024, he delivered a talk on Indian caste dynamics at an event hosted at the University of Oxford. He is also scheduled to lead a session on race and mental health at the International Sociological Association (ISA) Conference in Morocco in July 2025.
Research themes
Bhoi's research primarily investigates the intersections of social stratification, education, and mental well-being, with a particular focus on marginalised communities in India. A central theme in his work is the concept of caste in everyday life, where he moves beyond structural analysis to explore the psycho-social and emotional experiences—or "affect"—of caste discrimination. His scholarship frequently examines the barriers Dalit and Adivasi students face in accessing higher education, and how neo-liberal policies of privatisation have impacted educational equity. Furthermore, Bhoi connects these sociological inquiries to public health, analysing how experiences of stigma and humiliation can shape mental health and overall well-being.
Awards and recognition
* British Sociological Association (BSA) Research Event Grant, awarded to fund a workshop on "Diversity and Inclusion in Higher Education."
* Dr. Ambedkar International Centre Fellow Award (2020–2023), from the Government of India.
* Dr. Ambedkar Foundation’s Study Tour Grant (2015–2016), from the University Grants Commission, New Delhi.
* Multiple travel and conference grants from institutions including the International Institute of Social Studies (The Hague) and the International Sociological Association.
Publications
Bhoi has published on topics of caste, education, and the psycho-social experiences of marginalized communities.
Books
*
He has several forthcoming books, including Performing Caste, Sensory Experience, and Everyday Sociality (Routledge) and Educational Privatisation, Higher Education and Dalits in Academics (Routledge).
Selected articles and book chapters

* Bhoi, D. (2023). "[https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-031-30655-6_3 Caste, experience and psycho-emotional feelings of Dalits in higher education]." In D. Bhoi & H. Gorringe (Eds.), Caste in Everyday Life: Experience and Affect in Indian Society (pp. 55-79). Palgrave Macmillan.
* Bhoi, D. & Lakra, N. R. (2022). "[https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/2455328X221129453 Marginality, Educational Opportunity and Access to Higher Education: Experiences of Scheduled Caste and Tribe Students in India]." Contemporary Voice of Dalit, 15(1), 7-23.
* Bhoi, D. (2022). "[https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/2455328X211073207 Economic Growth, Development and Education of Scheduled Castes: Line Drawn from Neoliberal Era]." Contemporary Voice of Dalit, 14(2), 173-189.
